So I know who you are. Yes. But for the sake of record, can you tell me what is your name
and where were you born? Right, my name is Bhuanesh Napao and I was born in the lovely
island of Mauritius. What part of Mauritius? I was born in a town called Florial and Florial
is one of the rainiest part of Mauritius. Mauritius is a volcanic island so where we
live in Florial there's a tourist destination where you can actually see a volcanic hole.
So tell me about growing up in Florial. Is that how you pronounce it? Florial. It's like
butter but it's not. Oh yes it is isn't it? I never thought of that. So what was it like?
What do you remember? When I ask these questions feel free to give as much or as little detail
as you want. It's up to you and the purpose of those questions is just to help us try and
recollect things. We probably don't talk about much anymore. So yeah what was it like growing
up in Florial for you? For me it was a lovely experience, probably my best experience really.
I grew up with my grandparents in sugar cane fields and there were cows, there was chickens,
there was hens and then obviously having to come to London with all its buildings was a bit of a
shock. But growing up in Mauritius I really liked it. I remember my grandparents, it was like a barn
it seemed like from childhood because I came to this country when I was seven,
like the cows were behind us and we were sort of like sleeping like in a barn house. It had beds
in there so I really liked the smell of the cows and the cow dung because that's what I grew up with
so that was really nice. The reason why my grandparents looked after me because I had
one older brother and two older sister and one younger than me. So they came to this country
obviously to make a better living. I think I was about two when I was left with my grandparents
so they brought my brother over first, then my two sisters so we stayed with my
grandparents. But I just remember you know how free it was, having my little dress and running
barefooted you know and having all the nature, coconut and mango trees and all these lovely
things around you in the sea and seeing my grandad cutting down sugarcane, that was nice
and obviously eating the sugarcane, I loved it. Going to sugarcane factory and getting you know
everything was about sugarcane. So that was really nice and I remember my grandmother,
she's the one that tended the cows so she would be milking the cows and would be drinking fresh
milk. When you come to this country and you drink the milk you think what am I drinking?
Because the milk was so fresh so we'd have cow's curd milk, cheese you know and I remember she
used to walk the cows probably maybe to sell the milk or maybe sell the cow, I don't know where it
was but yeah that was nice just you know having my grandad sort of picking us up and giving us
milk and fresh eggs, fresh vegetables that were grown so yeah so I really miss all that.
So what age did you leave? So I came here, I should leave at the age of seven
and I remember you know everybody coming, they did show us pictures of my parents,
said this is your mom, this is your dad, you're going to go to London and I remember on the day
we were leaving I said I don't want to go and I ran into the sugarcane fields and they had to come
looking for me. I thought well where am I going, why are they taking me away from this place or the
people I love you know. Yeah and then when I did leave my parents came to meet us and I remember
you know she gave this apple and the apple looked huge and I thought I've never seen a huge apple,
like it was a big red apple and we were eating it on the coach and I was looking out of the window
and the sky was grey, the building was grey, I couldn't see any palm trees, I couldn't see any
greenery so it was a bit of a shock for me but then when I did go to my parents house they
lived behind them, it wasn't like a railway station like the, I felt like the railway children
because they always had the train running across and we used to wave at the people but that's a,
it's no longer a railway, it's now become like a nature reserve so it was nice to see some trees
at the back of the house so that was nice. So what do you remember of your childhood that
became a fond deep memory for you, how did you play, you know what things do you
talk about in terms of your childhood still to today? I think I always go back to Mauritius
actually because those were the fondest of my memories, like you know writing on slate
with in our pen and paper so my grandad had a shop as well so we wrote on slate in school and
I remember sitting in school and outside were banana trees and if I'd got bored I'd look out
and I remember one day it was really raining and I'm watching monkeys eating bananas, you know
I think nature is really fun for me, this is why what I do today is try and get people into nature
for them to promote their mental health and their well-being because I grew up in nature
and I miss that and that's what I always strive to look for but in coming to London you know
that was nice as well because I was reunited with the family, I was with my mom, I was with my dad
getting to know them and you know he was quite strict so from my grandparents is very fond and
loving and that freedom and then suddenly you can't run around the house, the ceiling is going to
fall down you know all that sort of thing we're jumping on the bed you can't jump on the bed
you know and it was because we were on a high rise and one day the ceiling did fall
you know because the way the houses are built so it's always sort of like
you know thinking something's going to break or whatever
so yeah it was nice we used to sort of play rounders in the garden
so this is in the UK yeah so you had a garden yeah we had a garden
that was nice and again have to be careful when we're playing rounders and things you know
we'd be told oh you've stepped on the flowers you stepped on this thing your ball's gone on the

yeah I remember Diwali because Diwali is like Christmas everything's lit up everybody put
